PM

The ECB meeting on Thursday this week is loaded with expectations from markets
and investors. What might be the outcome and the likely impact on European
equities?
Our central expectations are for a further 10bps cut in the deposit rate to -0.3%
and an extension of the QE programme by 3-6 months. But there is a vast
smorgasbord of options open to the ECB and in the past they have been creative
with some of their policy solutions.

PM

Where are market expectations?
We would argue that if the ECB failed to deliver, this would be taken badly by
equity markets. The Stoxx 600 has rallied c.6% since the "pre-announcement" at
the previous meeting, part of this on the hope for more policy response from the
ECB. There has also been a spike in QE mentions on newswires.

PM

Spike in QE mentions?

11:12 am
PM

We should add to that

PM

QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE QE

PM

At our European conference (November 10-11) we surveyed investors and
corporates about their expectations for ECB QE: half the investors responding saw
a greater than 60% probability of QE being extended on December 3. Corporates
were much more uncertain. Interestingly, when asked when they thought QE in
Europe would end, over half felt not until 2018 or beyond.

11:13 am
PM

What's different this time round?
Equity markets have given up much of their post-QE gains – the Stoxx 600 is now
just 6% higher than on January 22 - and more particularly, within the market
cyclicals have now underperformed defensives by 5% since QE1 was launched,
despite the strong initial rally.
However, we would argue that the announcement effect on equities of QE2 will
likely be less than that of QE1 given: (1) this is an extension rather than new policy
tool, and (2) the backdrop in emerging markets has deteriorated since January.
Nevertheless, we would expect it to be somewhat supportive for equities if
confirmed and in particular see it as one of 4 potential catalysts for a turn in the
performance of cyclicals against defensives.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 93.75, up 1.87 (+2.04%), High: 93.75, Low: 89.43, Volume: 18.95m
BE

Credit Suisse saying it looks cheap, sort of.

11:21 am
BE

Event: On 10th December the company will provide an update on guidance for 2016+. While we don’t see this as a major catalyst, it forms part of a steady stream of updates that we expect over the next six or so months.
GLEN is one of several major miners that have significantly underperformed since mid-2015 due to high debt levels. Lower copper prices remains a key risk, but unlike peers GLEN’s marketing business continues to generate considerable cash flows and this, coupled with asset sales, should allow debt levels to fall over the next 12 months and insulate the balance sheet.
■ Marketing: seen as a 'black box' this part of the business continues to divide opinion and the company's through cycle guidance ($2.7-3.7bn EBIT) looks optimistic in the current price climate. The issue of limited disclosure is unlikely to be addressed in the near term, but this business continues to underpin group cash flows. Based on targeted RMI reductions, zinc and copper production curtailments and comparing to previous trough cycles (early 2000s, 2009) we forecast $2.3-2.4bn EBIT for 2016, slightly below 2015 guidance of $2.5-2.6bn.
■ Copper: as the company's biggest exposure copper prices will remain a key driver. Copper industry margins are approaching previous low cycle points and we do not see supply as a major threat. Demand remains the problem and as outlined in a recent note (Metals and Mining - Supply performance is diverging, but more cuts may be needed), further industry cuts may be required before prices recover.
■ Valuation: 2016E cash earnings multiple is c10x (FCF yield 10%) compared to peers on north of 20x. At spot prices the industrial business is trading c4x EV/EBITDA compared to peers on c10x.

BE

What might get overlooked is that a 40% divi cut is actually a cancel.

11:26 am
BE

Or could be, depending on how management phrases it.

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Change in dividend: With the highest dividend yield in the FTSE (13.3%), the market clearly believes this is not sustainable. As we wrote in our Mining and the progressive dividend dilemma note in June, it was always going to be hard for the companies to keep progressive dividends given the diversified model is on its knees, payout ratios greater than 100% being unsustainable (AAL is at 122% for 2015E and EPS negative in 2016E on spot) and deteriorating cashflow is leaving dividends uncovered on spot for the next four years. As such, management are likely to move to adopting a c.30-40% payout ratio, in our view. On spot, a 40% payout for 2015 would imply no final dividend (as interim dividend greater than 40% FY payout) and 2016 would imply complete suspension of the dividend – so a complete cut cannot be ruled out. On our commodity price and fx forecasts, a 40% payout implies a 83% cut to the 2016 dividend.

11:27 am
BE

And Credit Suisse, saying (as we have, repeatedly) that Anglo might be in trouble but probably doesn't need a rights issue. Probably.

BE

■ Balance sheet: a dividend cut is now broadly expected (we model a move to a 40% pay-out policy) but the debate has now moved quickly on to whether Anglo requires additional capital. Anglo has good liquidity and we do not expect the group to protect the investment grade credit rating. The company will reach full targeted production capacity and ex-growth capex levels by late 2016 and this will be the key test to whether Anglo can manage its existing debt levels.

BE

11:36 am
BE

That's a risky approach, particularly when you have a 12% short.

BE

Barclays has a very very long summary of the main points.

BE

Aberdeen reported a set of in line P&L figures for FY15 but slightly disappointing Qtr to Sep outflows and downbeat management outlook. This was counterbalanced a little by modest surprises on the FY15 dividend at 19.5p with 5.8% yield. FY15 operating profit of £498m is in line with our forecast of £497m with revenues and costs are also roughly in line. Lower than expected finance income causes a small PBT miss at £492m vs our forecast of £498m but lower tax rate causes a small diluted EPS beat of 1% at 30p for FY15. Q4 (qtr to Sep) outflows of -£12.7bn is worse than the -£10.3bn we were forecasting with the driver being (as expected) Equities outflows of -£8bn (-4bn out of Asia-Pac, -£1.8bn out of GEM and -£1.9bn out of Global Equities all for Q4). AUM at end of Sep at £283.7bn is -8% qoq and in line with our estimate. Management outlook appears downbeat saying the “the current weakness may have some way to run” so those hoping for more optimistic update for Oct/Nov may well be disappointed. The Aberdeen share price has underperformed ytd at -23% (FTSE100 -3%) but has enjoyed a small bounce in Oct/Nov partly on bid spec and partly on hopes that EM/Asia-Pac could rebound some time soon.

11:36 am
BE

FY outflows of -£33.9bn is higher than the -£31.5bn we expected which implies -£12.7bn outflows in the qtr-to-Sep, sequential deterioration vs -£10bn in qtr-to-Jun. This was driven by -£7.9bn from Equities, -£2.1bn from Fixed Income and Properties each, and -£0.7bn from Property. Within Equities the qtr-to-Sep outflows were driven by -£4bn from Asia-Pac and -£1.8bn from GEM and Global Equities each. This brings FY Equities outflows to -£16.4bn (o/w -£6bn from Global, -£5.7bn from Asia-Pac, -£4.1bn from GEM). Within Fixed Income, EM Debt saw outflows of -£1.4bn in qtr-to-Sep which was a significant deterioration vs previous qtrs. Sep-15 closing AUM was broadly in line at £284bn vs our forecasted £283bn driven by slightly milder negative market movement than forecasted.

BE

Management provided a downbeat outlook for the near term indicating that challenging market conditions are expected to continue into 2016, although they remain convinced EM fundamentals will return in the long run for the ‘patient’ investor. They describe Asian and Emerging markets are undergoing a cyclical correction and anticipate the current weakness may have “some way to run”. This is disappointing given investors were perhaps hoping for a better flow outlook in Oct/ Nov, following -£34bn outflows already in FY15. Management indicate they will remain focused on controlling costs, particularly back office and support costs and manage cash flows to mitigate the impact of outflows

BE

Y15 Dividend per share was announced at 19.5p, up 8% yoy and translating to a dividend yield of 5.8%. Although consistent with a progressive dividend policy, this is still a positive surprise, 3% ahead of our forecast of 19p and 1% ahead of consensus expectations of 19.3p, reflecting a solid balance sheet and cash flow generation.

11:37 am
BE

...... On the divi, incidentally, did Aberdeen ever say it wouldn't do double-digit growth this year?

BE

Its guidance was for double-digit growth. Consensus didn't expect it, of course, but I'm not sure management ever 'fessed up that it wouldn't meet the target.

BE

That's me being picky, perhaps.

11:38 am
BE

The share price has underperformed ytd down -23% vs the FTSE100 -3%. However, the share enjoyed a bounce in Oct/ Nov up 13%, perhaps on investor expectations of slowing outflows from EM/ Asia Pac and partly on bid speculation which the company has since denied (FT, “Aberdeen in search for buyer as emerging markets take toll”, 25 Oct 2015). The share is currently trading at 13.4x calendar 2016E PE, a slight discount to the sector average of ~14.5x.

Hacker group calling themselves Armada Collective, seeking ransom in bitcoin from domestic banks in order not to damage the electronic trading systems and have given deadline expires today. As state bank sources in "K" is not a question of transaction security as the threat does not concern interception of data or accounts but massively "click" on the websites of banks to "fall" under the weight of heavy traffic. To address cyber-attack set up a special team from the National Intelligence Service, the Computer Crime, banks and the Bank of Greece. The hackers had caused last Thursday the oligoplepti interruption of internet banking three banks, as a warning shot. Hackers demanded a ransom by threatening that if the requirements are not met to date Monday, November 30, will resume their attack the computer systems of banks. As state bank sources in "K" is not transaction security issue arises because the threat does not concern data interception or accounts but massively "click" on the websites of banks to "fall" under the weight of heavy traffic. In this way, temporary non-functioning of banks, will cause disruption of electronic transactions. Great is the mobilization of OTE and other providers to increase capacity and not achieve the goal of extortioners for temporary closures websites of banks. The sygkentrimeni team seems to have hit and Switzerland before about a month. The special response team set up by the weekend in order to ensure the smooth operation of the websites of banks. In any case banking sources reiterate that there is no theft issue, bill, card or personal information related to the security of transactions. Head of the Task Force on tackling cyber is Mr. George easter, member of the Bank of Greece. The Armada Collective is a relatively new group of hackers launched similar attacks to those against the Greek banks last September. The approach followed is similar to that of electronic extortion of another hacker group that called «DD4BC».

11:52 am
BE

On Friday afternoon Stock Spirits brought forward its trading update
originally scheduled for Monday morning, indicating that its full-year
EBITDA was likely to fall well short of the previously guided range of
EUR60m-68m. Guidance has been reduced by c20% to EUR 50m-54m and
we have zero visibility for next year. We have little confidence in
management’s ability to turn around the Polish business as the business
faces serious structural headwinds. We downgrade to Hold and reduce our
price target to GBp131.

BE

● Order patterns: Stock suffered from irregular order patterns from key
customers. Some accounts have delayed purchases in the hope of
extracting better terms in December, while others have failed to honour
prior commitments following weaker demand. Stock has no recourse over
its customers and management is not confident the November shortfall
can be made up in December – hence the warning.
● Competitive pricing: We have underestimated CEDC’s ability to maintain
its aggressive promotional stance. CEDC has shown an indifference
towards returns and instead cut prices even further in Q3. This, coupled
with competitive pricing from reinvigorated peers (Marie Brizard, Pernod
Ricard), resulted in Stock’s volume share falling to 29.5% in September
(31% in Q2 2015 and as high as 38% in H1 2014).

BE

● Channel shift: Stock overindexes to the traditional trade, a channel that is
now being structurally challenged by the rise of discounters (Biedronka,
Lidl). The discounter channel is growing by 12% while traditional trade is
declining by 6%, affecting both sales growth and margin expansion.
Discounters can only grow if they receive support from suppliers, and it is
clear that all of Stock’s peers are providing this. Unfortunately, this is
something we had not foreseen.
● No plan B: On the conference call management failed to reassure investors
that it had a plan B. The priority is to retain the delayed orders and to
simply make it to the end of the year. The cost base is already lean so we
see limited room for margin improvement. Unfortunately, it is not clear
that management knows how to return to growth in Poland. The CFO
indicated that Stock is still looking for M&A, but we believe that this would
be unpalatable to investors at present. The company needs the strength of
its balance sheet.
● Valuation: On our revised forecasts, Stock trades on 15.0x FY 2016 P/E, at a
30% discount to the sector. Cash generation remains strong, but after two
profit warnings it may just be that investors appreciate that Stock hangs on
to its strong balance sheet.

11:56 am
PM

Here's a snap from Singer

PM

BCA is benefiting from growth in end markets, as well as a structural shift towards auctions. New leadership is more engaged with the OEMs, as evidenced by a new contract win, and activity levels already appear to be benefiting. With a market-leading proposition and a broadening range of services, BCA is well placed to continue growing market share too. Increasing its penetration of existing and new services (e.g. buyer finance) is driving profit per unit metrics. Alongside a clear strategy to deliver efficiencies on top of the natural operational leverage, these dynamics result in a clearly positive outlook. Barriers to entry are high and its physical portfolio impossible to replicate. Today’s results look to be at the upper end of market expectations and risk could be to the upside.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 377.24, up 10.74 (+2.93%), High: 377.24, Low: 362.60, Volume: 333.97k
PM

11:59 am
PM

omg smile

BE

Page one ..........

BE

■ Three key events – one past, one future, one possible – will drive Ocado's
share price over the medium term, in our view. We have reduced our FY15
and FY16 EBITDA forecasts slightly, but maintain our Outperform rating and
current Target Price of 466p.
■ Event one – the coming of Amazon: Reports of Amazon's entry into home
delivery for groceries spooked investors, causing Ocado shares to fall 15%
over the 10 days after the stories first appeared. We were less troubled
given the very modest success of AmazonFresh in the US market. However,
Amazon Pantry is much more concerning, as it plays to Amazon's strengths
and exploits the weaknesses of the existing home delivery model.
■ Event two – a third-party deal: Ocado's self-imposed deal deadline (YE15)
is approaching fast. Buyers may be wary of the very high complexity
involved in a transaction, but the real roadblock is more likely the fear of
cannibalisation of their existing operations. Without online competition in
their respective home markets, the incentive to stay on the side-lines is high.
■ Event three – an outright acquisition: We list a number of reasons why
we believe an acquisition of Ocado makes sense. We see Amazon and Wal-
Mart as most likely to benefit strategically from a tie-up with Ocado.

12:03 pm
BE

Ocado has neither the balance sheet, brand, management depth, nor the mandate to
expand internationally. Those limitations underpin why they are trying to commercialise
their technology by using partners rather than by expanding their own operations. But
many potential purchasers are focused on their home markets, which, as noted above,
introduces the strong likelihood of cannibalisation.
Ocado's technology enables rapid expansions into new markets, using less capital than a
traditional store network build-out would entail. Even in low-growth markets, market share is available if you can take it away from incumbents (like the Discounters are doing in the
UK), and is where a winning online offer can become a genuine disruptive technology.
With a market capitalisation of ~$3bn, Ocado is a small enough to be bought by a wide
range of companies, but two companies stand out: Amazon and Wal-Mart. Neither has
publicly expressed any interest in acquiring Ocado, but both have characteristics that
make a potential acquisition of it compelling:
■ Few cannibalisation concerns;
■ Balance sheets that would allow roll-outs to multiple countries simultaneously;
■ Global brands with global ambitions;
■ Global supplier relationships; and
■ A strong interest in grocery.
Almost as important, by buying Ocado, that technology would then become unavailable to
their competitors.
We would also consider other larger retailers who have the ambition, vision, and balance
sheet to embrace a fundamental change in the way they do business. We would include
Tesco and Carrefour in this list.

BE

And here's why it won't.

BE

Wal-Mart has been redeveloping its e-commerce platform (their "Pangea" project), which
will have at least some overlap with Ocado's technology. We also know that Wal-Mart has
a lot on its plate right now, and while the financial cost would be minor, it would be
stretched from an operations management perspective. We think any transaction that puts
a greater burden on management would be taken as a negative by the market.
Amazon is more opaque. Their AmazonFresh operations in the US are barely past the trial
stage. However, if they were getting reasonable returns we would expect them to expand
operations to the 85% of Americans who are not within the current catchment areas.
Instead, they are looking to initiate operations in the highly competitive UK market with
multiple entrenched online operators. The reasons behind a UK launch may be as much
for corporate learning as it is for pure growth.
From an Ocado perspective, although control is in the market, we believe a successful
transaction would have to be friendly. The high operational complexity requires in-depth
institutional knowledge, so management’s cooperation would be fundamental to any deal,
in our view.
The "build it yourself" option is often cited as a reason not to employ Ocado's technology,
and the same reason can be used to argue against buying the firm as a whole. But
although we believe Ocado's technology can be replicated (and in a shorter time period
than it took Ocado), we are unsure whether the trade-off between "capital" and "time to
market" would be worth it.
